channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Obama Ends Exemption for Cubans Who Arrive Without Visas
item.media:description: President Obama during his farewell address in Chicago on Tuesday.
item.description: The unexpected change to a policy unique to Cubans has long been sought by the Cuban government.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Taiwan Works to Keep Its Central America Friends (Among Its Few)
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras at the presidential palace in Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, on Monday. Taiwan has diplomatic relations with only 20 countries, along with the Vatican; the largest cluster of those is in Latin America and the Caribbean.
item.description: President Tsai Ing-wen is in the region to shore up some of Taiwan’s formal diplomatic relationships as it faces rising pressure from China.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: A Voice for Indigenous Canadians Defends His Claim to Be One
item.media:description: The Canadian author Joseph Boyden at the Edinburgh International Book Festival in Scotland. After nearly three weeks of silence, Mr. Boyden defended his claim to indigenous ancestry this week in two interviews and a news release.
item.media:credit: Russell G Sneddon/Writer Pictures, via Associated Press
item.description: A report by an indigenous television network in Canada challenged the indigenous ancestry of Joseph Boyden, author of “The Orenda” and other novels.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: A Soccer Star Caught in Poverty, a Risky Trip, and a Sorrowful End
item.media:description: Women walked past a stall selling cola nuts in Banjul, Gambia. The cost of living has soared in the country, prompting thousands of Gambians to try to reach Europe.
item.description: Fatima Jawara, a Gambian goalkeeper, tried to follow the path of many African migrants: the “back way” across the Mediterranean to Europe. She was lost at sea.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: United States to Lift Sudan Sanctions
item.media:description: United Nations peacekeepers at a refugee camp in Sudan on Monday. In exchange for the lifting of United States trade sanctions, Sudan has said it will improve access for aid groups, stop supporting rebels in neighboring South Sudan and cooperate with American intelligence agents.
item.description: For the first time since the 1990s, the country will be able to trade extensively with the United States.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: With Electricity in Short Supply, 10,000 Protest in Gaza, Defying Hamas
item.media:description: About 10,000 Palestinians took to the streets in the Jabaliya refugee camp on Thursday.
item.description: Demonstrators hurled stones and burned tires outside an electric company near a refugee community to voice their displeasure with worsening power shortages.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Banker Inspired by Western Novelists Seeks to Build Asia
item.media:description: Jin Liqun, 67, head of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, hopes to steer the bank toward building environmentally friendly infrastructure in a way that is free of corruption.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: Jin Liqun, who runs the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, says Faulkner helped him understand complex human relationships.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Chinese State Media Denounce Rex Tillerson’s Call to Block Island Access
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson, the nominee for secretary of state, at his Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday. He said that Beijing’s fforts to build islands in the South China Sea, and to equip some with military equipment, were illegal.
item.description: One newspaper warned of “large-scale war” if the United States intervened in the South China Sea, as Donald J. Trump’s nominee for secretary of state suggested.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Sinosphere: China Says It Will Ban Abuse of Children at Internet Detox Camps
item.media:description: Students at the Qide Education Center, a military-style boot camp in Beijing for internet addiction, in 2014. Experts welcomed a draft law that would ban abusive treatment at internet detox camps in China.
item.description: Electroshock therapy and beatings at the boot camps have prompted outrage. Experts welcome the ban but wonder whether it will be enforced evenly.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Philippine Police Arrest 2 More in September Bombing of Night Market
item.media:description: Mourning the victims of the night-market bombing in Davao City, in the southern Philippines, in September. After the attack, President Rodrigo Duterte declared a regional state of emergency.
item.description: At least seven people had previously been arrested in the Davao City bombing, with the police saying they belonged to the Maute militant group.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Erdogan Says Troops Will Be in Cyprus ‘Forever,’ Complicating Hopes of Reuniting
item.media:description: A man on Thursday crossed a United Nations buffer zone that divides an area controlled by Greek Cypriots and one controlled by Turkish Cypriots in Nicosia.
item.description: The Turkish leader, however, often takes a firmer line with domestic audiences than with foreign ones, and diplomats said they remained cautiously optimistic.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ANDREAS RIRIS

item.title: Antony Armstrong-Jones, Photographer and Earl of Snowdon, Dies at 86
item.media:description: Antony Armstrong-Jones in New York for an exhibition of his photographs in 1975.
item.description: He married Princess Margaret, the sister of Queen Elizabeth II, in 1960, and plunged into a life of privileges, parties, quarrels and infidelities that ended in divorce 18 years later.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: Tristram Hunt, Labour Lawmaker, Resigns to Lead V&A Museum
item.media:description: Tristram Hunt in Washington in December. Mr. Hunt has an impressive cultural résumé and has written several books, including a history of the English Civil War.
item.description: The move by Mr. Hunt, a historian and writer who was a critic of his party’s leftist leader, Jeremy Corbyn, will prompt an election in his vulnerable constituency.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: As Trump Reaches Toward Putin, U.S. Troops Arrive in Poland
item.description: Eastern Europeans were ecstatic when NATO voted to base troops in the region. But now, as they arrive, Donald Trump makes their mission less clear.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN and JOANNA BERENDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: Newfoundland Is Big on Bologna: Fried, Stewed and Layered Like a Cake
item.media:description: “The big stick,” a 9.7-pound bologna sausage encased in wax, from Maple Leaf Foods, is a big seller in Newfoundland.
item.media:credit: Antonio de Luca/The New York Times
item.description: A cookbook has 400 recipes for cooking with bologna, but never, its author advises, season it with curry.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Canada Today: Questioning a Writer’s Ancestry, Bologna Dogs and the Galloping Gourmet
item.media:description: The Canadian author Joseph Boyden at the Edinburgh International Book Festival in Scotland. After nearly three weeks of silence, Mr. Boyden defended his claim to indigenous ancestry this week in two interviews and a news release.
item.media:credit: Russell G Sneddon/Writer Pictures, via Associated Press
item.description: A broad debate about a prominent spokesman for indigenous people, the lowdown on a favorite Newfoundland dish and catching up with Graham Kerr.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Kitsch vs. Curios: Tourist Trade Threatens Character of London’s Portobello Market
item.media:description: Once an arcade with 200 antique dealers, the World Famous Portobello Market is now an open-plan gallery selling mass-produced souvenirs.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: Hordes of visitors descend on the famous stalls in Notting Hill, but many come for the cheap souvenirs rather than the valuable antiques.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT REYBURN

item.title: After 26 Days at Sea, Missing Father and Daughter Arrive in Australia
item.media:description: The catamaran, docked at a harbor south of Sydney, that Alan Langdon used to bring his six-year-old daughter to Australia from New Zealand, a trip of nearly a month.
item.description: New Zealand had been searching for the 6-year-old girl and her father since Dec. 26 following their disappearance after departing from a harbor there.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Rebel. Drug Fugitive. Hero? Haiti Erupts Over an Arrest
item.media:description: Guy Philippe, center, greeted villagers in his hometown of Pestel, Haiti, in October.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The arrest of Guy Philippe, the feared Haitian rebel leader recently elected as a lawmaker, shakes loose popular resentment of the United States.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Russian Proposal Would Phase In Cigarette Ban, but Current Smokers Get a Pass
item.media:description: Lighting up in a bar in Moscow in 2014, before Russia banned smoking in most public places.
item.description: The Health Ministry draft rules would ban the sale of cigarettes to people born in 2015 and after.
item.dc:creator: ROGENE JACQUETTE

item.title: C-Span Online Broadcast Interrupted by Russian Network
item.media:description: Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, in an image from C-Span on Thursday.
item.description: A feed from RT broke into Representative Maxine Waters’s speech on the House floor in midsentence, in what may have been a technical routing error.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: ‘Symbol of Hope’: U.N. Chief Says Deal to End Cyprus Divide Could Be Near
item.media:description: A Greek Cypriot soldier at the United Nations buffer zone in Nicosia, the divided capital of Cyprus.
item.description: At talks in Geneva, representatives of Britain, Greece and Turkey met with Cypriot leaders from both sides of the island nation, which has been divided since 1974.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ANDREAS RIRIS

item.title: Opposition Party in Poland Ends Monthlong Occupation of Parliament
item.media:description: The Polish Parliament on Thursday. A political crisis began on Dec. 16, when a lawmaker from Civic Platform, the main opposition party, stormed the parliamentary speaker’s rostrum to protest plans to curb the news media’s access to Parliament.
item.description: The protest by Civic Platform was directed at the right-wing government’s plan to curb the news media’s access to Parliament.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Banda Aceh Journal: As Shariah Experiment Becomes a Model, Indonesia’s Secular Face Slips
item.media:description: Religious officers led a youth onstage before a public whipping in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, in August. The youth was punished for dating outside marriage, which is against Shariah, or Islamic law.
item.description: In recent years, the Muslim-majority nation has drifted in a conservative direction, and a province dominated by the legal code of Islam is no longer an outlier.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT

item.title: Christopher Steele, Ex-Spy Who Compiled Trump Dossier, Goes to Ground
item.media:description: Journalists on Thursday outside the London offices of Orbis Business Intelligence Ltd., co-founded by the former MI6 agent Christopher Steele.
item.description: The former MI6 agent was said to have hurriedly left his home in southern England when he knew his identity was to be revealed.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Rex Tillerson’s South China Sea Remarks Foreshadow Possible Foreign Policy Crisis
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson, the nominee for secretary of state, told senators on Wednesday that China’s actions in the South China Sea were “akin to Russia’s taking of Crimea.”
item.description: In nomination hearings, Mr. Tillerson called for China to be denied access to its artificial islands, which would be a remarkable change in the U.S. approach to the disputed waters.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: South Korea’s Blacklist of Artists Adds to Outrage Over Presidential Scandal
item.media:description: The South Korean artist Hong Sung-dam in 2014 with his painting depicting President Park Geun-hye as a scarecrow. Mr. Hong is one of thousands of artists reportedly blacklisted by Ms. Park’s government.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: A blacklist by President Park Geun-hye’s government affected more than 9,000 artists, reports say, leading to introspection about the country’s authoritarian past.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Kunduz Attack in November Killed 33 Civilians, U.S. Military Says
item.media:description: Villagers gathering around some of those who were killed during heavy fighting in Boz Qandahari, in Kunduz Province, in November.
item.description: An investigation found that the firefight and airstrikes injured 27 others, American military officials said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: Talking to In-laws Can Be Hard. In Some Languages, It’s Impossible.
item.description: A geographically widespread practice known as avoidance speech imposes strict rules on how one speaks — or doesn’t — to the parents of a spouse.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Twitter Must Do More to Block ISIS
item.media:description: A woman is evacuated from the Bataclan theater after the shooting in Paris on Nov. 13, 2015.
item.description: The militant group uses the platform as a tool of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: ANNE CAMERON CAIN and BEATRIZ GONZALEZ
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Trump’s Pivotal Russian Test
item.media:description: A journalist holds a poster with portraits of President Vladimir Putin, Marine Le Pen and Donald Trump prior to Putin’s annual news conference in Moscow last month.
item.description: Hurtling into a love fest with Putin would be calamitous. Russia responds to toughness and Trump must show it or NATO and the E.U. could unravel.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The U.S. Must Talk to North Korea
item.media:description: The portraits of late North Korean leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang.
item.description: Bilateral diplomacy is the best way for the Trump administration to limit the growing nuclear threat.
item.dc:creator: SIEGFRIED S. HECKER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
